message: Are there any VMware fans out there? I've never used it for work, but I just installed player for the first time in years on my personal machine. My dedicated Linux laptop died, so I figured I would try running a VM on top of Windows 7. When I last tried Player years ago, the resolution was locked at something ridiculous that made web browsing impossible so I was skeptical, but after a couple of hours configuring things and setting up my VM I'm pretty impressed with it.
VMware is a good quick option, but if you were going to keep it like that i would take a look into virtualbox http://www.virtualbox.org/ it is really good
I'm really impressed with vmware fusion. Especially the Unity feature.
@italiano40 Thanks for the heads up. I'll have to check it out. What do you prefer about VirtualBox?
@JohnFail it is just open source and i feel the user has more control and i have an older computer so i like be able to control memory and things like that
@italiano40 Open source is always good. VMware Player lets you set the amount of RAM you want the VM to be able to access; does Virtual Box offer more granular control?
virtual box has more control i know VMware player has those controls, plus i am on mac so I really don't know about virtual box on windows, but virtual box is my goto VM creator and player
VirtualBox is great IMHO, I use it for a lot of stuff. Its the only virtualization tool that has an integrated iSCSI initiator.
I use VMWare Workstation and it runs faster than Virtualbox under the similar VM configuration.  Obviously, only vmware player and virtualbox are free; workstation is not.

Also that there are lots of free virtual appliances for VMPlayer / VMworkstation - http://www.vmware.com/appliances/ - it was one of the main decision factors for me to pay for the vmworkstation for local testing and prototyping.  

I'm unsure if there is a similar marketplace for virtualbox today.  At least, it didn't 3-4 years ago.
Most VM images will run on a variety of platforms assuming they were made properly. Virtualbox will run with VDI/VMDK images.
Yea I use the appliances all the time with my virtualbox and virtualbox is just as good as workstation
I tend to use VirtualBox for more routine tasks, such as a sandpit environment, but a properly setup ESX cluster with or without vsphere is a thing of beauty
Vmware workstation 7 is my first choice for virtualization! I tried all the others and vmware seems to be the most stable one without any hiccups.
I use VMware/VSphere at home and for work. And now that I have a iMac I use Vmware Fusion.
@dasmin5 actually I feel parallel is better than fusion, they have the same features but parallel just faster

@italiano40 I’d agree but the speed wasn’t worth the instability I had with Parallels. I’m hoping VM’s next upgrade for Fusion will be worth it. It seems to be that they alternate in speed every time they upgrade. Parallels 5 was fastest, when Fusion 3 was released, it was the fastest, and now Parallels 6 is the fastest. Hopefully, Fusion 4 will be much faster but with better stability than Parallels 6. I’m hoping Fusion 4 and the iOS app they have will work better together.
@MikeT parallels is really stable that has never been an issue i think i have 5 or 6 i don't remember, and what does the iOS app and fusion do together? that maybe a point for me to switch

@italiano40 The VMWare View for iPad only runs from VMWare View machines, requiring PCoIP protocol. If Fusion 4 supports that, the iPad app should be able to view it or they might have a separate VMWare Fusion App for iPad in the future.
IMHO VMware wins.  Better networking options and overall support. I've used Fusion, ESX, Virtualbox and xen and out of all of those, Vmware just seemed the most polished.
Test

VMWare/Parallels are likely superior for desktop application use; for development, VirtualBox wins hands down thanks to Vagrant: http://vagrantup.com -- super useful tool for spinning up/codifying developer VMs.
@bitprophet +1 Vagrant has totally changed how I work. It's fantastic.
Vagrant looks pretty cool, I'm gonna have to try it out.
